text.text_translated: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen (famous American singer) is still releasing new music. His music tops charts and fills stadiums. He is at the top of his game in his late 60s. I am not surprised at all. He tells us our most fundamental stories about ourselves. When you listen to Born in the USA (Springsteen album), his stories are still relevant.

feedback.feedback: Mixed B1 control. Keywords defined correctly: “Springsteen (famous American singer)” and “Born in the USA (Springsteen album)”. However, the first sentence is too long and cluttered: “Unlike many other famous album (music collection) artists, Springsteen (famous American singer) is still making hit, stadium (large sport area) concerts with new songs.” (~24 words, multiple parentheses). Fidelity issues: The original states he is “still releasing … new music”; you changed it to “still making … concerts,” which shifts from releasing music to performing shows. “Hit concerts” misrepresents “chart-topping” (charts measure songs/albums, not concerts). Another fidelity drift: “stories about ourselves” became “stories about people,” losing the first-person focus. Grammar/lexis are mostly B1 and simple in other sentences (“I am not surprised.”, “He is also very good at his work in his late 60s.”). Connectors are simple. Overall pass, but penalized for the long, complex first sentence and the meaning shifts.
